posts.name: William
posts.cooked:
I’ve been working on packaging the wpilibc library into a Conan package, see conan.io and WilliamBehrens/AllWpilibConan: Unofficial packaging of the Wpilib suite for Conan - NotABug.org: Free code hosting , I’ve also been creating a cmake template for developing control applications https://github.com/rr1706/FRCMakeTemplate .

I’ve posted about these before but that was mainly just to gauge interest and get some idea. This is more to say that the project if far enough along that outside feedback would be nice as well as a bit of guidance on packaging wpilib for conan.

Is the wpilib library found in wpilibsuite/allwpilib and built with cmake the same as the one pulled with gradle? because as far as I can tell the headers don’t exactly match what’s found in the wpilib documentation

also why is wpilib’s cmake install target so odd compared to other cmake libraries? what’s the point of it creating it’s own wpilib/ folder?

link_counts.title: WilliamBehrens/AllWpilibConan: Unofficial packaging of the Wpilib suite for Conan - NotABug.org: Free code hosting

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
Both gradle and cmake are built out of the wpilib repo. Differences are likely caused by the repo containing 2022 code, and the docs still being 2021 based.

One thing to note is that cmake can’t build libraries for the RoboRIO. It will only build desktop libraries.

The target is odd because that’s the only way I could figure out how to get things to work. Nothing else I tried worked. It does have some nice properties of not polluting the root library directory, which is nice though.

posts.name: William
posts.cooked: So i’ve noticed the issues I was having have to do with wpilibc itself only getting built with when using ./gradlew :wpilibc:build and not being included into the CMake target, as far as I can tell, so unless there’s a way to get wpilibc to build with cmake I’d have to create a very hacky packing script, which is fine, but is there a reason why wpilibc isn’t included with the cmake build?

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked: It’s just not enabled by default. There’s a cmake flag you have to pass to enable everything above network tables.

posts.name: William
posts.cooked: Thank you, I’ve found the issue, I was trying to build just wpilibc so I had java disabled. but disabling java disables building wpilibc

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked: That’s kinda weird. I’d expect it to just not build the JNI parts.

posts.name: William
posts.cooked: Ok cause I was thinking that was off, currently the only thing holding me back from packaging wpilib with conan is that java dependency. I keep getting an error saying it can’t find opencv java bindings. even after compiling and installing opencv with java support on my system. I would prefer to just be able to disable java and cscore as I don’t plan on using them but basically disabling any part except the tests prevent wpilibc from building

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked: I suggest opening an issue about this on https://github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib to get input from @Thad_House on build system modifications.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: You can’t disable cscore (as wpilibc requires it), but you should be able to build cscore with Java disabled (WITH_JAVA=NO), as the search for OpenCV Java in cscore/CMakeLists.txt only occurs if Java is enabled.  I concur with @calcmogul that this would probably be better discussed in a GitHub issue.

posts.name: William
posts.cooked: Just wanted to give an update, currently the conan packaging for wpilib is finished and working so I may submit it to the offical conan center index for easy of use by other teams soon but some other issues have come up. My team also uses the navx and sparkmax products in our robot often and those come with their own sdk that’s currently only packaged for gradle. So I’m going to package those for conan as well before progressing more with the template

posts.name: William
posts.cooked: Why exactly do the simulation modules require being compiled as shared libraries? is there some error that occurs if they’re not?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: They are optionally loaded at runtime, so they must be shared libraries.

posts.name: William
posts.cooked: I take it you mean just the halsim modules are loaded at runtime, so why cant they just be compiled as shared libs ignoring the shared flag? Unless im miss understanding

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
WilliamB:

compiled as shared libs ignoring the shared flag

Are you talking about why you can’t in the cmake build specify WITH_SIMULATION_MODULES=YES in combination with BUILD_SHARED_LIBS=NO?  The reason for this is that the simulation modules depend on and therefore need to link to other libraries (e.g. hal, wpiutil), and since the simulation modules must be shared libs, those libs must be shared as well in order to have both the user program and the simulation module use the same common data in those libs.
